Editor’s choice paper Carbon nitride as efficient catalyst for chemical fixation of CO2 into chloropropene carbonate: Promotion effect of Cl in epichlorohydrin Xianghai Song Yuanfeng Wu Donghui Pan Fufeng Cai Guomin Xiao ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Southeast University Nanjing China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Chemical fixation of CO2 into chloropropene carbonate over carbon nitride. As an abundant, nontoxic, cheap, and renewable carbon resource, carbon dioxide (CO2) has drawn much attention in recent years. The chemical fixation of CO2 for various synthetic transformations is a hot topic in current researches. In the present work, three kinds of carbon nitride (C3N4) were prepared and tested for the chemical fixation of CO2 to chloropronene carbonate (CPC). These catalysts were characterized by means of XRD, SEM, BET, IR, and XPS. The activity test demonstrated that u-C3N4 presents the best catalytic activity, which was attributed to the large amount of edge defects in the structure and its higher surface area. The superior reactivity of epichlorohydrin (ECH) compared with other epoxide was derived from the Cl atom in its structure, which can act as a co-catalyst for the reaction and activate epoxide group in ECH as well. The best result was obtained at 120°C, 2MPa initial CO2 pressure in 5hours with an ECH conversion of 98.31% and CPC selectivity of 98.01%. The catalyst can be reused for five cycles with only minimal decrease in catalytic activity. Moreover, based on the experimental and characterization results a possible reaction mechanism was proposed. Keywords Carbon nitride Carbon dioxide Epichlorohydrin Chloropropene carbonate 1 Introduction As a greenhouse effect gas, carbon dioxide is one of the main reasons for global warming. The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has significantly increased in the past decades due to the consumption of fossil fuels. Hence, CO2 has become to a main concern all over the world. On the other hand, CO2 is an inexpensive, abundant, non-toxic and renewable C1 resource. Therefore utilization of CO2 as raw material for synthesizing fuels and useful fine chemicals is an ideal approach to reduce CO2 and prevent possible global problems [1,2]. Catalytic coupling of CO2 with epoxides to form cyclic carbonates is the most efficient method among various means for CO2 application [3,4]. Organic cyclic carbonates can be used as electrolytic elements of lithium batteries, monomers for polymerization, organic intermediates for medicines and fine chemicals. Besides, cyclic carbonates, as aprotic solvents, are also widely used in chemical and pharmaceutical industries [5–8]. Over the past couple of decades, various catalysts, including homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, have been developed to catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. It is reported that metal-oxides [9], alkali metal salts [10,11], metal-salen complexes [12], ionic liquids [13–16], ammonium[17] and phosphonium salts[18] are all active for this cycloaddition reaction. Among the catalysts mentioned above ionic liquid is the most effective one. Generally, homogeneous catalysts such as alkali metal salts, ammonium salts are more active compared to heterogeneous catalysts. However, two serious drawbacks associated with homogeneous catalysts are the difficulty in catalyst recovery as well as product purification. As to heterogeneous catalysts, they can be easily separated from products by simple filtration, but surfer from poor catalytic activity or selectivity because of their limited surface area, thus requiring harsh reaction conditions. Recently, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are also found to be effective in the chemical fixation of CO2 into epoxides [19–21]. MOFs are superior to other heterogeneous catalysts due to their porous nature, large surface area and easy modification. However, many MOFs need to catalyze the reaction in the presence of a solvent or co-catalyst, which complicates the reaction process. Besides, the cost of MOFs is less competitive compared to other heterogeneous catalyst which limits their industry application. Therefore, the development of a new catalyst which is highly active, easy recovery and low cost is still highly desirable. Recently, carbon nitride (C3N4), as one of the versatile metal-free materials, has received increasing attention and found its application in a variety of fields such as photocatalysis [22], fuel cells [23], gas storage [24], and catalysis [25]. The incorporation of N atoms into carbon nanostructure endows C3N4 with quantities of basic sites which enable C3N4 to be a potential catalyst for CO2 conversion. Since the first reported about CO2 activated by mesoporous graphitic canbon nitride (mpg-C3N4), the application of carbon nitride as catalyst for CO2 conversion has been gradually reported. Su et al. reported urea-derived graphitic carbon nitride (u-g-C3N4) as an efficient catalyst for CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates [26]. The incompletely coordinated nitrogen atoms, which are also named as edge defects, in low polymerization degree of u-g-C3N4 were thought to be active center for CO2 activation (Scheme 1 ). Later, n-bromobutane was incorporated into mesoporous carbon nitride structure and used as a catalyst for solvent free cycloaddition of CO2 to propylene carbonate [27]. Besides, it was reported that the combination of carbon nitride and metallophthalcocyanine as bifunctional catalyst exhibit good catalytic activity for CO2 chemical fixation as well [28]. However, these reactions suffer from some drawbacks such as high reaction temperature, high catalyst loading amount, long reaction time. Interestingly, it was found that when epichlorohydrin (ECH) was utilized as reactant for CO2 chemical fixation, the reaction can be achieved with high efficiency under mild reaction conditions in the presence of C3N4. But the reason for the high reactivity of ECH is still unclear. To the best of our knowledge, there is no research focus on the reasons for this phenomenon. In this work, various carbon nitrides were prepared and tested for the chemical fixation performance of CO2. Various experiments were performed to get a deeper insight into the reaction pathway. Additionally, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed for the excellent performance of ECH in chemical fixation of CO2. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemicals in this work were commercially available and used without further purification. Melamine (99%) was purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. (Shanghai, China). Urea (99%) was obtained from Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd. Ethylenediamine (99%), Carbon tetrachloride (99.5%), 1,2-epoxypropane (99.5%) and ECH (99.5%) were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). SBA-15 was purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co.,Ltd. Carbon dioxide (CO2 >99.9%) was obtained from Nanjing Special Gas Factory Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The urea derived C3N4 was synthesized according to literature [29]. Typically, 25g of urea was dried in a crucible at 80°C for 12h, thereafter the covered crucible with urea was placed in a muffle furnace and heated at 550°C for 3h to complete the reaction. The thus obtained powder was washed with nitric acid (0.1M) and distilled water, then dried at 80°C for 12h to get the slight yellow product. The catalyst was noted as u-C3N4. The catalyst marked as m-C3N4 was prepared by direct treatment of melamine at high temperature in air atmosphere. In a typical synthetic procedure, 5g of melamine was placed into a quartz boat and heated in a tube furnace at 550°C for 4h with a heating rate of 2°Cmin−1. The yellow product was grounded into powder for further use. The template based s-C3N4 was prepared according to literature [30]. Typically, SBA-15 (0.5g) was added to a mixture of carbon tetrachloride (5.4g) and ethylenediamine (2.2g). The resulted mixture was refluxed at 90°C for 6h. The thus obtained dark-brown mixture was dried at 80°C for 12h and then ground into a fine powder. Then the powder was heated at 600°C for 5h with a heating rate of 3.0°Cmin−1 in nitrogen atmosphere. After removing the silica framework in 5wt.% hydrofluoric acid, followed by filtration, washing with ethanol and drying at 100°C, the mesoporous carbon nitride was obtained as a black power. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were recorded on an Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (40kV and 40mA) as the X-ray source. The scanning range (2θ) was from 20 to 75°, with a scanning rate of 20°min−1 and a step function of 0.02. The morphologies of the synthesized catalysts were studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images using a Philips XL-30 ESEM operating at a voltage of 10kV. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured by static N2 physisorption at −196°C with a Beishide 3H-2000 analyser. The surface area was calculated using the multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore volume and pore size were calculated from desorption branches of the isotherms with the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The surface functional groups of the catalysts were determined by fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR) using a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the wavenumber range of 400–4000cm−1 with KBr pellets as a reference for the measurements. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. Mg Kα radiation (1253.6eV) was used as the X-ray source at an ultrahigh pressure of 3.0×10−7 mbar. The collected elements binding energy (BE) were calibrated by referencing the C 1s peak at 284.6eV. The precision of BE was within±0.1eV. 2.4 Catalytic activity test The cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with ECH to prepare 3-chloro-1, 2-propylenecarbonate (CPC) was performed in a 100mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer. Typically, 20mL (23.62g) of ECH, and 0.12g of the catalyst were added into the reactor at room temperature. Then, the reactor was pressurized with CO2 to a desired pressure and heated to the desired temperature at a stirring rate of 600r/min for a designed time. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the excess CO2 was vented slowly. The catalyst was separated from the reaction system by centrifugation. The product was analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC-6890, China), equipped with a flame ionization detector and a capillary column (SE-30, 30m×0.25mm). The reaction products were identified by GC-MS (Agilent 6890) equipped a HP-5 capillary column (30m×0.32mm) with He as carrier gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization XRD patterns of C3N4 prepared from various raw materials and the recovered u-C3N4 are presented in Fig. 1 . Clearly, both m-C3N4 and u-C3N4 show intensive diffraction peak at 27.5° and a small diffraction peak at 13.2° (Fig. 1a and b). The peak at 27.5° relates to the (002) plane of C3N4, which is characteristic interplanar stacking structure of graphitic-like materials[31] and the peak at 13.2° is indicative of in-planar structural packing [25]. The (002) peak of m-C3N4 is more intense compared with u-C3N4, implying the crystallinity or condensation degree of the m-C3N4 is superior to that of u-C3N4. This means u-C3N4 possesses more edge defects which are active for the activation of CO2, matching well with the superior catalytic activity of u-C3N4 to m-C3N4. On the other hand, s-C3N4 synthesized with SBA-15 as a hard template shows a broad peak at around 25° and no peak at 13.2° (Fig. 1c), indicating the poor crystallinity of s-C3N4. This may result from the partial collapse of interlayer units of C3N4 in mesoporous materials while removing the SBA-15 template [27]. Besides, the edge defects of s-C3N4 may also be damaged due to HF leaching treatment during the SBA-15 removal, which accounts for its low catalytic performance. The recovered u-C3N4-5re exhibits a sharp decrease in (002) peak compared with the fresh u-C3N4, accompanied with the disappearance of the (001) peak at 13.2°. This may result from the catalytic reaction in which process u-C3N4 interacts with reactant and causes some changes in its structure. To survey the surface morphology of the catalyst, SEM micrographs of the three C3N4 materials were obtained and shown in Fig. 2 . Clearly, m-C3N4 displays amorphous, tightly stacked blocky structure (Fig. 2A). The catalyst m-C3N4 is synthesized by condensation of melamine at elevated temperature in the absence of any template, which may account for its tightly stacked structure. Unlike m-C3N4, u-C3N4 is composed of quantities of amorphous fine particles with large amounts of space among these grains (Fig. 2B). The porous structure is derived from the CO2 produced in the production of u-C3N4 from urea, which can act as a soft template for the catalyst. Interestingly, s-C3N4 is short-bar like and loosely stacked morphology. Moreover, hollow, tubular structure is also observed in this micrograph (Fig. 2C). The special structure of s-C3N4 is attributed to the template SBA-15, whose porous structure offers a special template for C3N4 to condense. After the removal of template by HF, C3N4 in the pore of SBA-15 is left with regular short bar and hollow, tubular structure. In addition, compared with fresh u-C3N4, the recovered u-C3N4-5re shows a little increase in particle size, which may result from the adsorbed product on the recovered catalyst. Besides, reaction between u-C3N4 and reactant may also be responsible for the larger particle size for recovered catalyst. To further investigate the physical and chemical properties of these catalysts, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of m-C3N4, u-C3N4 and s-C3N4 are shown in Fig. 3 . Clearly, both m-C3N4 and u-C3N4 exhibit type IV isotherms with deep hysteresis loops (Fig. 3a and b), indicating the existence of slit-shaped porous structures in the m-C3N4 and u-C3N4 particles. As for s-C3N4, it displays a complex isotherm which seems to be a combination of various isotherms (Fig. 3c). The marked increase in the N2 amount adsorbed at low pressures is ascribed to the presence of micropores. The large hysteresis loop at P/P0 =0.44–0.84 is associate with quantities of mesopores in s-C3N4, which is result from the remove of template SBA-15. In addition, the small hysteresis loop at P/P0 >0.93 is assigned to the macropores of this material, which may originate from the interparticle void. As can be seen in Table 1 , the BET surface of m-C3N4, u-C3N4 and s-C3N4 are 27.76, 46.10 and 575.10m2 g−1 respectively. The super surface area of s-C3N4 is attributed to its ample porous structure, as can be seen from SEM micrographs and isotherms. The CO2 produced in the production of u-C3N4 explains the larger surface area of u-C3N4 compared to m-C3N4, in accordance with the SEM results. In this regard, u-C3N4 is more reactive than m-C3N4 due to its more exposed active sites. To investigate the function groups on the C3N4 prepared by different methods, the FT-IR spectra of u-C3N4, m-C3N4 and s-C3N4 are acquired and presented in Fig. 4 A. Obviously, all samples display a broad absorption bands in the region of 1200–1650cm−1 which are attributed to the typical stretching modes of C3N4 heterocycles [32]. However, compared with u-C3N4 and m-C3N4, s-C3N4 exhibits weak absorption band in this region, implying the poor C3N4 heterocycles structure of s-C3N4 (Fig. 4A–c). The sharp absorption band at 810cm−1 in u-C3N4 and m-C3N4 is assigned to the breathing mode of the triazine or heptazine units of C3N4 materials [31,32]. However, the absorption peak at 810cm−1 for s-C3N4 is rather small. This means that there are only a few triazine or heptazine rings in the s-C3N4 molecular, indicating the poor condensation degree of this sample which is consistent with the XRD results. The intense broad absorption band around 3141cm−1 observed in all the samples is assigned to stretching vibration modes for the NH, NH2 and OH of the adsorbed H2O [33]. The NH and NH2 are originate from the edge defects of C3N4 materials, they can be considered as an indirect indicator of the C3N4 condensation degree. The peak intensity of edge defects decreases with increasing C3N4 condensation degree. Moreover, the edge defects are active center for CO2 activation, thus its content is greatly related to the activity of the C3N4 materials. Absorption peak intensity of these materials at around 3141cm−1 are of the order u-C3N4 >m-C3N4 >s-C3N4, matching well with the activity order. The poor edge defects content of s-C3N4 may derive from the damage during removal of template SBA-15 by HF. The FT-IR spectra of recovered catalysts are given in Fig. 4B. It can be seen that no obvious changes are observed after two cycles (Fig. 4B–d). Even after five cycles, the catalyst u-C3N4 remains almost unchanged compared with the fresh one, except that a small absorption band appears at 1804cm−1. This band may result from a little product adsorbed on the surface of recovered catalyst [28]. Therefore, the catalyst u-C3N4 is quite stable under reaction conditions with excellent reuse ability, in line with the experimental results. To figure out the main chemical components and active groups of the prepared catalyst, XPS measurements of u-C3N4 and recovered u-C3N4-5re were performed and the results are given in Fig. 5 . Clearly, u-C3N4 surface is mainly composed of nitrogen and carbon. Based on the peak area calculated from XPS, the molar ratio of carbon to nitrogen on u-C3N4 surface is 0.57 which is lower compared with the theoretical value 0.75, implying incomplete crystallization. Besides, a small amount of oxygen is observed, this may be assigned to the adsorbed water or some intermediate in condensation [27,34]. The N 1s peak intensity decreases dramatically in recovered u-C3N4-5re accompanied by a significant increase in C 1s and O 1s peak intensity. In addition, the Cl 2p peak is also observed in recovered u-C3N4-5re. This may be attributed to the product adsorbed on the catalyst, matching well with IR analysis. Moreover, the incorporation of ECH into u-C3N4 structure, due to the high reactivity of ECH, may account for another reason for this phenomenon. To further elucidate the chemical states of u-C3N4 and the chemical states variation before and after catalytic reaction, deconvolution of N 1s has been performed and the result is presented in Fig. 6 . There are three peaks included in the N 1s spectra, implying the existence of three different types of N bonding functions in u-C3N4 (Fig. 6A). The intense peak with a binding energy of 398.6eV is ascribed to the N atoms in triazine or heptazine rings which is bonded to two atoms (CNC) [35]. The peak at 399.3eV is attributed to the sp2 hybridized N bonded to three atoms (CN(H)C or CN(C)C). The small peak at 400.6eV is assigned to the sp3 terminal N (NH2 or NO) at the edges of u-C3N4 materials [26,36]. It is worth noting that the intense peak at 398.7 ev decreases dramatically in the recovered catalyst u-C3N4-5re. Bulk phase of u-C3N4 is more easily covered by adsorbed species compared with the edge of u-C3N4 may be responsible for this phenomenon. Additionally, the binding energies of all these three peaks shift to higher value, indicating changes in chemical bonds in the recovered u-C3N4-5re catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic activities 3.2.1 Catalytic activities of various C3N4 materials As reported, C3N4 materials are active for CO2 transformation to useful fine chemicals [37]. In this work, three kinds of C3N4 were prepared using different methods and their catalytic activity were tested through the reaction of CO2 with ECH, by means of propene oxide conversion and CPC selectivity. In addition, the catalytic activity of melamine for this reaction was also investigated as control (Table 2 ). Clearly, among the catalysts investigated, u-C3N4 exhibits the best catalytic performance to give an ECH conversion of 98.31% with a CPC selectivity of 98.01% at 120°C in 2h (Entry 2). Though, m-C3N4 shows almost the same ECH conversion (95.55%) and CPC selectivity (97.03%) to u-C3N4, it requires quite a long reaction time of 5h (Entry 1). The superior catalytic activity of u-C3N4 to m-C3N4 may be attributed to its larger surface area and more edge defects which enable more active centers exposed to substrate, in accordance with the BET and IR analysis. Nevertheless, s-C3N4 displays a rather poor performance towards this reaction only with an ECH conversion of 42.57% in 5h, which is opposed to its high surface area. This may be attributed to the low edge defects content in its structure, which are damaged in the removal of template SBA-15 by the treatment of HF [26]. Besides, the overall carbon to nitrogen ratio of s-C3N4 is 3.48:1 [30], which is higher compared with 0.57:1 for u-C3N4, implying fewer nitrogen atoms or less active sites in s-C3N4. This may also account for the low catalytic activity of s-C3N4. The result is in line with the poor NH and NH2 concentration in s-C3N4, as detected in FT-IR spectra. Additionally, melamine is also highly active for this reaction with an ECH conversion of 93.04% and a CPC selectivity of 84.25% in just 1h, which is more reactive than u-C3N4 in terms of ECH conversion (Entry 4). As the only functional group in melamine, NH2 group is undoubtedly the active center for CO2 conversion. This is also indirect evidence that the edge defects NH or NH2 in C3N4 materials are the active sites for CO2 activation. The NH2 group in melamine is quite reactive, which enable it to react with ECH or the product. This may account for the low selectivity of melamine towards CPC. 3.2.2 Effects of reaction parameters As mentioned above, u-C3N4 presented the best catalytic performance, it was further investigated to get the optimized reaction conditions, and the results are given in Table 3 . Clearly, no product was obtained in the absence of catalyst (Entry 1). The yield of product remarkably increased with increasing catalyst loading from 16.94% to 91.52% when the catalyst loading raised from 0.1wt.% to 0.3wt.% (Entry 2 and 3). Along with the catalyst amount increased to 0.5wt.%, a product yield of 95.99% was achieved (Entry 4). The yield of product did not increase markedly with further increase in catalyst loading, and reached 96.28% in the presence of 1wt.% catalyst in 2h (Entry 5). However, when 0.5wt.% catalyst was adopted only 87.05% yield was obtained in 2h (Entry 6), indicating both catalyst loading and reaction time is crucial for this reaction. It is interesting to observe that, the selectivity towards product decreased with the increase in catalyst amount, from 99.68% for 0.1wt.% to 98.01% for 1wt.% (Entry 2–5). This may be due to the increasing NH or NH2 amount with the increase in catalyst amount, which can react with ECH or product, in agreement with the result of melamine. The effects of reaction temperature on ECH conversion and product selectivity are also summarized in Table 3. Clearly, temperature has a positive influence on the cycloadditon reaction. When the reaction was performed at 100°C, only 19.74% of ECH conversion was achieved (Entry 8). However, the ECH conversion significantly increased to 68.42% at 110°C (Entry 7), and further rose up to 97.59% with the temperature reached to 120°C (Entry 6). This might be attributed to the more effective collisions between reaction substrates and the active sites of catalyst at elevated temperatures [13,38]. In addition, the selectivity of CPC somewhat decreased with the increase in reaction temperature from 99.50% to 98.50% (Entry 6–8), implying more side reaction occurred at higher temperature. Given the results above, the reaction conditions was set as 120°C, 0.5wt.% catalyst loading, and 5h. Reactor stirring speed was investigated to survey the effects of mass transfer on the reaction, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . It was found that the product yield increased with time, accompanied by gradual decrease in reaction rate. However, no obvious changes in product yield were observed with various stirring rate from 400 to 800r/min, indicating the effect of mass transfer has minimum effect on product yield when the stirring rate beyond 400r/min [39]. The stirring rate utilized in our experiment was 600r/min, so the mass transfer has little effect on the results. 3.3 Reusability of the catalyst Reusability is one of the major criterions to assess a heterogeneous catalyst. The reusability of u-C3N4 in the cycloaddition reaction of ECH with CO2 was tested and displayed in Fig. 8 . As can be seen, there is only a minimal decrease in the conversion of ECH after five runs, from 98.31% to 88.51%. Meanwhile, the selectivity towards CPC almost remains the same level as fresh u-C3N4 after five cycles. Hence, the catalyst is rather stable under reaction conditions, in accordance with the IR results. The decrease in catalytic performance of u-C3N4 may be related to the leaching of catalyst in the recycling process. Besides, the changes in catalyst structure may also contribute to the decreased catalytic activity as depicted in XRD spectrum. 3.4 Possible reaction mechanism Though the cycloaddition reaction of epoxide and CO2 can be catalyzed by pure u-C3N4, it needs to be performed at harsh conditions such as high temperature, high CO2 pressure, large amounts of catalyst loading and long reaction time. Whereas, when it comes to ECH, the reaction goes well in the presence of pure u-C3N4 at mild reaction conditions with short reaction time and high yields. But the reason for this phenomenon is still unclear. Zhang et al. utilized metallophthalocyanine carbon nitride hybrid as catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction of ECH with CO2 and observed an induction time [28]. They attributed this induction time to the slowly produced Cl− which was derived from the reactions of C3N4 with the chloromethyl of ECH. However, no induction time was observed when pure u-C3N4 was used as catalyst in this work (Fig. 7). Besides, the reaction was achieved in a much shorter time (5h) compared with the catalyst mentioned above (28h). To get a deeper insight into the mechanism of the cycloaddition of ECH with CO2 in the presence of u-C3N4, propene oxide (PO) was utilized as a comparison (Table 4 ). Clearly, the conversion of PO was only 5.01% when u-C3N4 itself as catalyst (Entry 1). As well known, halogen anions in ionic liquid and quaternary ammonium salts are highly active for the cycloaddition of CO2. However, no obvious increase in PO conversion was observed when 1.0wt.% KI was adopted as a co-catalyst (Entry 2). On the contrary, the conversion of PO dramatically rose up to 98.44% when KI was replaced by tetrabutyl ammonium bromide (TBAB, Entry 3). This intense contrast may be due to the poor solubility of KI in PO compared with TBAB. In addition, 1, 2-dichloroethane (DCE) was used as both co-catalyst and solvent in this reaction, but only 1.98% of PO conversion was achieved, implying DCE hardly give any Cl− in the presence of u-C3N4 (Entry 5). To figure out whether ECH gave out Cl− upon interaction with u-C3N4, a mixture of PO and ECH was used as reactant to perform the cycloaddition reaction with CO2 (Entry 6). Apparently, 20.65% of PO conversion was obtained which is superior to the reaction with only PO as reactant (5.01%), indicating the presence of Cl− in the reaction system. This means the reactivity of Cl atom in ECH is superior to that in DCE. Moreover, 80.65% of ECH conversion is lower compared with pure ECH as substrate (98.31%), which may result from the diluted Cl− concentration. The excellent reactivity of ECH compared with PO should be assigned to Cl atom in ECH molecular. The existence of Cl atom could activate the epoxide group in ECH, and facilitate the ring opening of the epoxide group and thus the reaction of ECH with CO2. Given the results above, it is reasonable to make four hypotheses: (1) The Cl atom in ECH can be activated by epoxide group through intramolecular interaction, which makes it easy to leave. (2) The left Cl− functions as a nucleophile for the epoxide ring opening to promote the cycloaddition of ECH with CO2. (3) As an electron-withdrawing substituent, Cl atom can also activate the epoxide group in ECH, which makes its ring opening easier compared with PO. Besides, Cl atom serves as a stabilizer for the chloroalkoxy anion intermediate formed by epoxide ring opening (Scheme 2 ). (4) The left Cl− and u-C3N4 with the aid of Cl atom in ECH synergistically catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of ECH to CO2 with high efficiency. Moreover, it was reported that edge defects (NH and NH2) are active centers for CO2 activation [26,40–44]. Together with the experimental results, characterizations, and the works reported previously [14,27,45,46], a possible reaction mechanism for the cycloaddition of ECH with CO2 catalyzed by u-C3N4 has been proposed, and illustrated in Scheme 2. First, the edge defects NH or NH2 of u-C3N4 react with reactive Cl atom of ECH to release Cl− anion. Meanwhile, ECH and CO2 are activated through hydrogen bond and defects N respectively to give off intermediate I and activated CO2. Then Cl− anion attacks the activated epoxide group in ECH and leads to the formation of intermediate II. In this step, the ring opening can be easily achieved with the aid of neighboring Cl atom, and the chloroalkoxy anion (intermediate II) is rather stable due to the existence of two electro-withdrawing Cl atoms. After that, the subsequent intermediate II react with activated CO2 to generate intermediate III which is a liner chlorocarbonate. Thereafter, the line chlorocarbonate transforms into CPC via intramolecualr substitution of Cl atom. At the same time, the catalyst u-C3N4 is recovered with a little modification. 4 Conclusion In this research, u-C3N4 was successfully synthesized by simple pyrolysis of urea at elevated temperature. The edge defects originated from the incomplete condensation of u-C3N4 were thought to serve as active sites for CO2 activation. It was found that u-C3N4 is highly active for cycloaddition of CO2 to ECH compared with other epoxide. This is because the Cl atom in ECH can activate its neighboring epoxide group and facilitate the ring opening of epoxide in the reaction process. Owing to the interaction between Cl atom and epoxide group in ECH, u-C3N4 can easily reacted with ECH to give out a small amount of Cl − anion which acts as co-catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction. The resulted Cl − and u-C3N4 synergistically catalyzed the reaction with high efficiency. Besides, the reaction was performed at relative mild conditions and the catalyst was highly recyclable. coredata.dc:description: As an abundant, nontoxic, cheap, and renewable carbon resource, carbon dioxide (CO2) has drawn much attention in recent years. The chemical fixation of CO2 for various synthetic transformations is a hot topic in current researches. In the present work, three kinds of carbon nitride (C3N4) were prepared and tested for the chemical fixation of CO2 to chloropronene carbonate (CPC). These catalysts were characterized by means of XRD, SEM, BET, IR, and XPS. The activity test demonstrated that u-C3N4 presents the best catalytic activity, which was attributed to the large amount of edge defects in the structure and its higher surface area. The superior reactivity of epichlorohydrin (ECH) compared with other epoxide was derived from the Cl atom in its structure, which can act as a co-catalyst for the reaction and activate epoxide group in ECH as well. The best result was obtained at 120°C, 2MPa initial CO2 pressure in 5hours with an ECH conversion of 98.31% and CPC selectivity of 98.01%. The catalyst can be reused for five cycles with only minimal decrease in catalytic activity. Moreover, based on the experimental and characterization results a possible reaction mechanism was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Carbon nitride as efficient catalyst for chemical fixation of CO2 into chloropropene carbonate: Promotion effect of Cl in epichlorohydrin
